deliberation: Formulaic heading. Considered whether “the word of YHWH” is figurative. It is a standard prophetic metonymy for divine revelation, but no extended imagery beyond that.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD
instances.explanation: “Word” stands for the whole revealed message of God, a metonymy where a single speech unit represents extended divine revelation.

deliberation: Purely historical-prose superscription naming Egypt, Pharaoh Neco, Nebuchadnezzar, dates and locations. No comparisons, personification, or idiomatic expressions beyond normal narrative usage.
Literal military commands to prepare shield and buckler and approach battle. No overt metaphors or similes; armor and battle remain literal.
Further literal military imperatives (harness horses, mount riders, helmets, spears, armor). No figurative transfer of meaning; all terms refer to actual equipment and actions.

The verse vividly describes panic and retreat. The key idiomatic prophetic slogan is “terror on every side,” which treats terror as if it surrounds like an enemy force. Other phrases (fleeing, being struck) can be literal in battle context.

instances.english_text: Terror all around!
target: The pervasive fear of the Egyptian troops
instances.explanation: The abstract emotion ‘terror’ is depicted as if it physically surrounds them like an enemy encirclement, an idiomatic personifying metaphor typical of Jeremiah.

deliberation: Describes swift ones and warriors unable to escape and physically stumbling and falling by the Euphrates. The language fits literal battlefield catastrophe; no clear figurative extension beyond vivid description.
Rhetorical question introducing imagery of rising like the Nile and surging like rivers. This is a clear simile anticipating the identification of Egypt as the subject.

instances.hebrew_text: מִי־זֶה כַּיְאֹר יַעֲלֶה כַּנְּהָרוֹת יִתְגָּעֲשׁוּ מֵימָיו
instances.english_text: Who is this that rises like the Nile, whose waters surge like the rivers?
instances.explanation: The unnamed force is explicitly compared to the Nile and surging rivers, highlighting its apparent irresistible rise and expansion.

deliberation: Egypt is explicitly identified and likened to the Nile with surging waters (similes). The boast “I will cover the earth” is hyperbolic imagery for universal conquest, not literal global flooding.

instances.hebrew_text: מִצְרַיִם כַּיְאֹר יַעֲלֶה וְכַנְּהָרוֹת יִתְגֹּעֲשׁוּ מָיִם
instances.english_text: It is Egypt that rises like the Nile, whose waters surge like rivers
vehicle: the Nile and rivers in flood
posture: setting up contrast with divine judgment
instances.explanation: Egypt is directly compared to the Nile and surging rivers, portraying its power and advance as a flooding river.

instances.english_text: I will rise, I will cover the earth
vehicle: covering the whole earth (as with water or a garment)
instances.explanation: Egypt’s boast to ‘cover the earth’ uses spatial imagery for universal conquest, a hyperbolic metaphor that exaggerates its reach to total global coverage.

deliberation: Horses and chariots are directly addressed and told to advance and ‘rage.’ This apostrophe and use of a verb of wildness for chariots personifies the war machines.

instances.english_text: Advance, O horses, dash madly, O chariots!
target: The onset of battle by Egypt’s forces
vehicle: horses and chariots behaving like frenzied beings
posture: vivid, almost mocking animation of Egypt’s military
instances.explanation: Inanimate chariots are urged to ‘dash madly,’ treating them as sentient, wild combatants to dramatize the rush into a doomed battle.

deliberation: Two prominent images: (1) the sword ‘devours,’ is ‘sated,’ and ‘drinks’ blood—strong personifying metaphor; (2) the battlefield as a ‘sacrifice’ prepared by YHWH, casting the slaughter in cultic terms.

instances.english_text: The sword shall devour; it shall be sated and drunk with their blood
target: The killing power of warfare against Egypt and allies
posture: intensely negative evaluation of the conflict
instances.explanation: The impersonal sword is portrayed as a living being that eats and drinks blood to satiety, vividly personifying the violence of war.

instances.english_text: For my Sovereign GOD of Hosts is preparing a sacrifice
target: The mass killing of Egypt’s armies at Carchemish
vehicle: a sacrificial ritual offered to God
ground: solemn, irreversible giving over to death
posture: theological interpretation of battle as divine rite
assertion of YHWH’s sovereignty over history
instances.explanation: The battlefield slaughter is conceptualized as a ‘sacrifice’ offered by YHWH, casting the victims as offerings in a ritual of judgment.

deliberation: Egypt is addressed as ‘virgin daughter Egypt’—national personification. Also a medical-healing metaphor: going to Gilead for balm, multiplying remedies, but there is ‘no healing’ for a national calamity.

instances.english_text: Fair Maiden Egypt / Virgin daughter Egypt
ground: contrast between former security and coming violation
instances.explanation: Egypt is personified as a virgin daughter, evoking youth, beauty, and vulnerability in ironic contrast to her coming defeat.

instances.hebrew_text: לַשָּׁוְא הִרְבֵּית רְפֻאוֹת תְּעָלָה אֵין לָךְ
instances.english_text: In vain do you seek many remedies; there is no healing for you
posture: pronouncement of hopelessness for Egypt’s recovery
instances.explanation: Egypt’s national disaster is cast as an incurable disease, with ‘remedies’ and ‘healing’ used metaphorically for political solutions that cannot succeed.

deliberation: ‘Nations have heard your shame’ and ‘your scream has filled the earth.’ The second is an obvious hyperbole/metaphor for widespread notoriety of Egypt’s distress.

instances.english_text: your screams have filled the earth
target: The notoriety of Egypt’s suffering and defeat
posture: emphasizing the breadth of her humiliation
instances.explanation: Egypt’s outcry is said to ‘fill the earth,’ a hyperbolic metaphor indicating that her distress has become universally known.

deliberation: Heading introducing another oracle, with literal reference to Nebuchadnezzar coming to strike the land of Egypt. No figurative expressions.
Calls to proclaim and take positions are literal. The phrase “the sword has devoured around you” is a recurring personifying metaphor, as earlier in v.10.

instances.english_text: For the sword has devoured all around you
target: The surrounding slaughter in regions near Egypt
ground: consuming and removing what is there
instances.explanation: The impersonal ‘sword’ stands for warfare and is personified as a devourer, stressing the destructive spread of conflict around Egypt.

deliberation: Asks why Egypt’s champions are ‘swept away’—a metaphor of being carried off by flood or force. YHWH’s ‘thrusting down’ is anthropomorphic but consistent with literal divine agency in battle imagery.

instances.english_text: Why are your stalwarts swept away?
vehicle: objects swept away by a current or force
instances.explanation: The mighty warriors are depicted as things ‘swept away,’ evoking the image of being carried off helplessly by a stronger force.

deliberation: Describes many stumbling and falling over one another, which can be literal battle chaos. The phrase ‘because of the deadly sword’ (or ‘sword of the oppressor’) uses ‘sword’ as a metonymy for warfare and killing.

instances.english_text: because of the deadly sword
ground: association of the sword with battle and death
the sword as emblem of war
posture: emphasizing mortal threat of the invasion
evoking fear as reason to flee
instances.explanation: ‘Sword’ stands metonymically for the entire warfare and its lethal threat, with the specific weapon representing the whole onslaught.

deliberation: Pharaoh is mockingly nicknamed ‘Shaon’ (uproar/braggart) who has let the appointed time pass. This functions as an ironic metaphorical epithet highlighting empty noise instead of decisive action.

instances.english_text: Pharaoh king of Egypt: ‘Braggart who let the hour go by’
instances.explanation: Calling Pharaoh ‘Shaon’ metaphorically reduces him to mere noise, an ironic nickname criticizing his boastful inaction as the critical time passes.

deliberation: YHWH swears by himself and compares the certainty/visibility of what is coming to Tabor among the mountains and Carmel by the sea. This is a double simile stressing inevitability and conspicuousness.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי כְּתָבוֹר בֶּהָרִים וּכְכַרְמֶל בַּיָּם יָבוֹא
instances.english_text: As surely as Tabor is among the mountains and Carmel is by the sea, so shall this come
target: The coming of the decreed judgment/invader
vehicle: Mount Tabor among mountains; Mount Carmel by the sea
posture: strengthening the credibility of the oracle
instances.explanation: The arrival of God’s decree (or invader) is likened to the obvious presence of Tabor and Carmel in the landscape, highlighting its certainty and conspicuousness.

deliberation: Egypt is again addressed as a female inhabitant (‘daughter Egypt’), personifying the nation. ‘Prepare your baggage for exile’ can be literal instruction, though it has a grimly ironic tone.

instances.english_text: Fair Egypt, you who dwell secure (lit. ‘O inhabitant, daughter Egypt’)
target: The Egyptian nation and its populace
vehicle: individual woman living in a place
ground: contrast between current comfort and coming exile
instances.explanation: Egypt is personified as a daughter-inhabitant, highlighting her feeling of secure residence just as she is told to pack for exile.

deliberation: Two linked animal images: Egypt as a ‘beautiful heifer’ and the northern invader as a ‘gadfly’ that comes against her. Both are metaphors casting political entities as animals in an agrarian scene.

instances.english_text: Egypt is a handsome heifer
ground: suitability as a victim of attack/slaughter
posture: ironically highlighting Egypt’s vulnerability in her prosperity
instances.explanation: Egypt is depicted as a beautiful young cow, suggesting prosperity and appeal but also making her an obvious target for the ‘gadfly’ from the north.

instances.english_text: A gadfly from the north is coming, coming!
posture: belittling portrayal of the invader as a small yet painful agent of judgment
instances.explanation: The northern invader is characterized as a gadfly that comes to sting the ‘heifer’ Egypt, portraying the attack as sharp and inescapable.

deliberation: Egypt’s mercenaries are likened to ‘stall-fed calves’—a simile stressing pampered softness and unpreparedness for battle, in contrast with the coming disaster.

instances.english_text: Her mercenaries in her midst are like stall-fed calves
ground: pampered, soft, and inexperienced in hardship
posture: critique of their unreliability and cowardice
instances.explanation: The mercenaries are compared to well-fed calves, stressing their pampered condition and explaining why they will turn and flee.

deliberation: Two explicit similes: Egypt’s voice going forth ‘like a snake,’ and invaders coming with axes ‘like woodcutters.’ Both are vivid comparisons, one for the sound of her retreat, one for the destructive work of the enemy.

instances.english_text: Her voice shall go forth like a snake
target: Egypt’s cry or sound in retreat
posture: depiction of Egypt’s reduced, fearful state
subtle mockery of her earlier boasting
instances.explanation: Egypt’s voice is compared to a snake’s movement/sound, suggesting a furtive, fearful rustling as she withdraws.

instances.english_text: They come against her with axes, like hewers of wood
ground: viewing Egypt as something to be felled
posture: frames the conquest as deliberate work
instances.explanation: The invaders are likened to woodcutters with axes, portraying their attack as the methodical chopping down of Egypt.

deliberation: Egypt’s ‘forest’ is to be cut down, likely a metaphor for her land/population/strongholds. Then the invaders are said to be ‘more numerous than locusts, without number’—a hyperbolic simile for overwhelming numbers.

instances.english_text: They shall cut down her forest—declares GOD
ground: density and breadth needing to be cleared
posture: depicts conquest as clearing away Egypt’s strength
instances.explanation: Egypt’s ‘forest’ likely represents her complex of cities and people, envisioned as a woodland to be felled by invaders.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי רַבּוּ מֵאַרְבֶּה וְאֵין לָהֶם מִסְפָּר
instances.english_text: For they are more numerous than locusts, and cannot be counted
ground: devouring presence across a wide area
posture: heightens fear of the invaders’ sheer numbers
instances.explanation: The invaders are compared to locusts in uncountable numbers, a hyperbolic simile underscoring their overwhelming multitude.

deliberation: Again uses ‘daughter Egypt’ as a personification of the nation. Shame and being handed over are literal consequences expressed in that personified framework.

instances.english_text: Fair Egypt (lit. ‘daughter Egypt’) shall be shamed
instances.explanation: Egypt is personified as a daughter who experiences shame, framing national defeat as a personal disgrace.

deliberation: God names Amon of No, Pharaoh, Egypt, her gods and kings. These are literal referents; ‘punish/visit’ is standard covenant language but not strongly figurative here. No clear metaphor or simile.
The phrase ‘those who seek their life’ is a standard Hebrew idiom for people trying to kill someone. The rest is literal transfer of power and later re-inhabitation.

instances.english_text: those who seek their lives
ground: pursuit aimed at taking life away
posture: emphasizes deadly intent of their enemies
instances.explanation: ‘Seeking someone’s life’ is an idiomatic way to say ‘seeking to kill them,’ where ‘life’ stands metonymically for the person’s existence.

deliberation: Addressed to ‘my servant Jacob’ and ‘Israel,’ where the ancestor’s name stands for the nation (metonymy). The rest speaks of literal restoration, calm, and quiet.

instances.english_text: My servant Jacob
target: The people of Israel as a whole
ground: corporate identity derived from an ancestor
posture: reassuring promise to the covenant people
instances.explanation: ‘Jacob’ functions metonymically for the descendants of Jacob, i.e., the nation Israel, addressed as God’s servant.

deliberation: Repeats ‘my servant Jacob’ with the same metonymy (ancestor for nation). The disciplinary language (‘chastise in measure, but not make a full end’) is covenantal but can be read literally as proportional national judgment.

instances.english_text: My servant Jacob
target: The exiled and scattered people of Israel
ground: representation of the whole by the ancestor
instances.explanation: Again, ‘Jacob’ stands for the entire people descended from him, a metonymy grounding the promise of presence and measured discipline.
